All sources and notes for further exploration of shadow, persona, and personality concepts.

Shadow References

  • Jung, C. G. (1968). *The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious* (Collected Works, Vol. 9, Part 1). Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí On the role of archetypes and the unconscious in shaping shadow material.
  • Jung, C. G. (1957). *The Practice of Psychotherapy* (Collected Works, Vol. 16). Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí Discusses projection, disowned aspects, and the therapeutic encounter with the shadow.
  • Beebe, J. (1994). *Integrity in Depth: Archetypal Explorations of the Persona, Shadow, and Complexes*. Routledge.
    ‚Üí Provides a functional and archetypal framework for understanding shadow dynamics within personality.
  • Nardi, D. (2011). *Neuroscience of Personality: Brain-Savvy Insights for All Types of People*. Radiance House.
    ‚Üí Offers empirical evidence on cognitive patterns that correspond to shadow and persona expressions.

RE:equip References

  • Jung, C. G. (1968). *The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious* (Collected Works, Vol. 9, Part 1). Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí On anima and animus as archetypal figures of the inner Other.
  • Jung, C. G. (1963). *Memories, Dreams, Reflections*. Vintage Books.
    ‚Üí An autobiographical account where Jung frames individuation as a lifelong journey.
  • Beebe, J. (1994). *Integrity in Depth: Archetypal Explorations of the Persona, Shadow, and Complexes*. Routledge.
    ‚Üí On archetypal roles and cognitive functions as tools for navigating life situations ‚Äî supports the ‚Äúre-equip‚Äù metaphor.
  • Nardi, D. (2011). *Neuroscience of Personality: Brain-Savvy Insights for All Types of People*. Radiance House.
    ‚Üí Maps cognitive functions to brain activity, showing how different mental ‚Äútools‚Äù can be flexibly accessed, aligning with the re-equip concept.

Persona References

  • Jung, C.G. (1981). *The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious*. Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí On archetypes as expressive tools for the psyche.
  • Jung, C.G. (1966). *Two Essays on Analytical Psychology*. Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí Covers Persona and individuation concepts.
  • Hillman, J. (1996). *The Soul‚Äôs Code: In Search of Character and Calling*. Random House.
    ‚Üí Explores character development and vocational expression.
  • Campbell, J. (1949). *The Hero with a Thousand Faces*. Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí Frames the archetypal journey relevant to Persona and individuation.

Self Page References

  • Jung, C. G. (1968). *The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious* (Collected Works, Vol. 9, Part 1). Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí Explores archetypes and unconscious patterns that shape personality and behavior.
  • Jung, C. G. (1963). *Memories, Dreams, Reflections*. Vintage Books.
    ‚Üí Jung‚Äôs reflections on personal development, individuation, and self-awareness.
  • Beebe, J. (1994). *Integrity in Depth: Archetypal Explorations of the Persona, Shadow, and Complexes*. Routledge.
    ‚Üí Provides insight into the Persona, Shadow, and archetypal dynamics in everyday life.
  • Nardi, D. (2011). *Neuroscience of Personality: Brain-Savvy Insights for All Types of People*. Radiance House.
    ‚Üí Maps cognitive patterns to brain activity, showing how personality types influence behavior and interactions.

RE:route References

  • Jung, C. G. (1960). *The Structure and Dynamics of the Psyche* (Collected Works, Vol. 8). Princeton University Press.
    ‚Üí On projection, transference, and the dynamics that shape relationships.
  • Jung, C. G. (1963). *Memories, Dreams, Reflections*. Vintage Books.
    ‚Üí Jung's reflections on encounters, relationships, and the transformative power of human connection.
  • Beebe, J. (2004). *Psychological Types, Jung's Model of Typology, and the Eight-Function Model*. In A. Sands (Ed.), *Personality Type: An Owner's Manual*.
    ‚Üí Introduces the archetypal roles of the eight functions, showing how conflict, projection, and resonance play out in relationships.
  • Nardi, D. (2011). *Neuroscience of Personality: Brain Savvy Insights for All Types of People*. Radiance House.
    ‚Üí Explores how different people show distinct neural engagement patterns, helping explain why interactions can feel harmonious, draining, or energizing.
